article.title: HADES RV Programme with HARPS-N at TNG VI. GJ 3942 b behind dominant activity signals

choices: The orbital period of the planet GJ 3942 b.
The distribution of instrumental drift in radial velocity measurements over time.
The correlation between the S index and radial velocity.
The change in the signal of the 6.9 day period over time.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the phase shift between the activity indices (S and Hα) and the radial velocity shown in Figure 2?
choices: The activity indices and radial velocities are unrelated.
The activity indices are not good proxies for magnetic activity.
There is a possible connection between the location of activity phenomena on the stellar surface and the observed phase shift.
The signal at 16.3 days is due to a planet.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is NOT supported by the GLS periodograms shown in Figure 3?
choices: The signal at 16.3 days is present in the radial velocity, S index, and Hα index data.
A significant signal at 6.9 days is present in the radial velocity data.
The window function significantly contributes to the identified signals.
After removing the 16.3 day signal, a signal at 10.4 days becomes more prominent in the radial velocity data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variation in the phase and amplitude of the sinusoidal fit to the RV data in Figure 4 suggest?
choices: A stable magnetic field on the surface of GJ 3942.
The presence of two planets with similar orbital periods.
Changes in the location, size, and strength of magnetically active regions on the stellar surface.
A systematic error in the RV measurements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 tell us about the signals at 16.3 and 6.9 days?
choices: Both signals are always present and easily detectable.
The significance of the 16.3 day signal increases over time, while the 6.9 day signal shows variable detectability.
The 6.9 day signal is likely due to stellar activity.
Both signals have the same False Alarm Probability (FAP) levels.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the coefficient "ϕ" represent in Formula (3)?
choices: The orbital period of the planet.
The amplitude of the radial velocity signal.
The correlation between radial velocities at consecutive times.
The decay time of the correlated noise.
